While I was hyped for this at first, being a extreme Dragon ball fan, from the original to Z, I even have a soft spot for the infamous GT. But this?! This is just a  giant middle finger for me and all other DB fans alike. This was supposed to be the first Dragon Ball series after nearly two decades, and I was super excited! It was gonna be awesome seeing a long beloved retro anime get fused with modern animation techniques and story telling. Too bad they lacked on not only animation, but even messed up the story telling! I mean, nearly 20years and a new series comes out, so we are expected an exciting pilot episode! One that will get us hocked to the series, like how most anime do, and leaving on a cliffhanger that launches the premise of the main story, but what we got was not a launching point, but mundane collection boring events that serves not to advance th story, but to patch up plot holes from the original story. In shorts, the first episode is essentially a filler. Next, I would like to address the animation issues. Episode 1-30 is a perfect example. But while online memes and other analysers have already covered those issues, my biggest problem is that the later episodes, while improved on the art department, failed to deliver on the action department. Instead of showing epic blood pumping battles, we are given the Z treatment, where they just drag around the same 4-5 frames of two or three people rapidly punching each other, something that we had seen over two decades ago in Z. We expected improved fighting were every move is unique, and any hit that misses or hits feel significant, but watch two blurry figures maybe land a hit. These rapid punch-and-dodge scenes might as well be a loading screen to who ends up hitting who. Even the energy beams lack substance. Instead of being a stream of near liquid like energy, disintegrating mountains and buildings, passing through them as if they weren't even there, they were reduced to a one colour laser beam that explodes on contact. Another problem I would like to address is the Goku is a fucking idiot in this show. I mean, he wasn't smart in Z nor the original, but Super's version would make Kid Goku from the start of Dragon Ball look like Einstein. He is just annoyingly happy all the time as long as it's not against the antag, and even then he still goofs around. Vegeta merely talks about his pride which he use to ACTUALLY SHOW! In fact, While Vegeta had it bad in Z, always being one step behind Goku, He still had a character, one that gets developed time and time again, but now? All he does is complain about Goku being stronger and straight up ditches his family to train with weis. But all of those problems, I can overlook, in fact, I would have actually loved this show had it not made one fatal mistake: The Gods of Destruction. \n\n
You see, back in Dragon Ball Z, the plot was improvised, and every arc was thought up on the fly. But what they all shared is that they tie in to the main story and don't feel out of place. Raditz and the Saiyans feel like they could exist in the DB universe because of Goku's tail and his Ozaru form. Namek feels like it belongs because of Piccolo. Cell and the Androids feels like they belong because of the RR Army! And while the Buu arc wasn't my favourite, at least the main Antagonist was actually threatening and the apocalyptic atmosphere, leaving a sense of dread that's only surpassed by the Androids in Future Trunks's timeline was amazing. But there was no hint of Gods of Destruction existing, yet all of a sudden, they were behind everything, and everyone in the series knew about them, why? Plus, some of what Beerus did made no sense, like when he claimed to have caused the dinosaurs to go extinct, despite the fact that dinosaurs clearly still live in dragon ball's earth. But most importantly, especially with the introduction of the omni-king, it eliminated the fear that "if you lose, this is the end" because we know the main characters have allies that are way stronger. And because of that, especially with the Universe Survival Arc, every fight feels like suspenseful because we know that A, they can get revived, And B, the Antagonist won't win anyway because of The gods, angels and Zeno. So none of the arcs actually put the earth in danger and only one that did was a mere competition with no actual enemies. Besides, it just makes Zeno look like an asshole instead of an actual enemy.

**This review might contain spoilers but I will try to warn**
Dragon Ball Super is the third canon sequel of the popular Dragon Ball series. This anime has been bothering me both by its content and by the extreme reactions its getting. Either fans are considering it a masterpiece or they are really disappointed. And as I was reading a lot of reviews were either full of praises or by people who dropped the series before actual content got any development so I decided to write a detail review (till episode 73).
First comes the question whether this series is recommended. If you have been a diehard DB series fan and loved it all these years in spite knowing its flaw then you definitely should give it a try. If you are just some one who liked the series or find it OK, well you may or may not watch, you can judge after reading this review and if you are someone alien to this series and thinking about starting from this part, don't bother because it is really not worth it. Rather you should either start from Dragon Ball (IF you like those adventurous type anime with somewhat an idiotic MC who somewhat becomes mature) or Dragon Ball Z (If you are into bad ass characters and intense fighting and not lengthy character development stuff).


Second from which episode should you start watching. As many of you might already be familiar that Dragon Ball Z had 2 new movies named "Battle of Gods(BOG)" and "Ressuruction of F(ROF)" and also a lot of you might also know that Dragon Ball Super that Super actually uses the content of its movie thus annoying fans by presenting them the content they have already watched. So unless you have a lot of time or you wanna note every single detail in series I would say just watch both of these movies, watch episode 1 and then start from episode 28 as movies have better animation and pacing.


Art (5/10)

Dragon Ball Super animation was stuff of memes at its release the animation of horrific,especially animation of episode 5 was so bad that it can probably give cancer . In next arc the animation became somewhat consistent but still really poor but since than it has improved and became a lot consistent by somewhat near episode 45. Though there are still noticeable flaws (in some frames) if you notice like unbalance eye level, some background characters not having eye but most of these are is scene of fast motion and some may also miss that old art style, but overall its not really that bad now (6 or 7 stuff).


Music (5/10)

The opening is somewhat ok, mostly nostalgic. The first ending was basically nostalgic as well. The second and third were really good but ever since that all ending basically looks like those of a comical gag anime (though super had been that way sometimes). The sound track in series has just been disappointing. There hadn't even been a noticeable sound track till fourth arc in which I liked few but overall the sound track had been worst in all canon and also GT. Also I am not really a big fan of DB Japanese voices but probably dub might be able to fix some problem.


 Story (6/10)

Again just like GT, Dragon Ball Super senselessly end up borrowing content from Dragon Ball.


(Spoiler: Read next line only if you have seen BOG or relevant episodes)


Among one common trait, they both introduce return of Emperor Pilaf out of oblivion.


Though unlike each other where Dragon ball GT adopted kid goku from DB, here the series takes the comical theme and which is by any means a horrible mistake. I mean seriously while in DB the theme was more comical but as the story progressed the theme becomes intense signifying growth and maturity but dropping it back to comical gag anime just was a change too big. Not to mention it is one of reasons why series hasn't been able to obtain as much intensity as its predecessors(not the major reason though).


Another thing Super has failed is the creativity of transformations. Even Toriyama admitted that. I am not saying they are concept wise the least creative but the execution really gives the sense. (The rest paragraph will contain some minor spoilers). The SSG is by far the most creative in terms of concept of achieving but the looks don't go with it and on top of that as soon as Goku transforms we hear someone say, you look the same. Oh this has got to be the worse way to bring down excitement seriously, in DBZ even on some new power up characters were like Holy shit what happened, though it was exaggeration but it did raised intensity. And then SSGSS, to be honest now some die hard fans will admit that series feel like they are just changing hair color and its in some words admitted by Toriyama as "Since I used red in BOG so it had to be blue.", seriously lacks creativity and also no proper explanation. Honestly Ascended Super Saiyan is by far the least creative transformation ever (considering u just trained in an isolated chamber for an year with changing physical condition and u receive a boost) it seemed still more creative than SSGSS which is actually the forth least creative transformation.


Now I will just generally discuss arcs since I cant spoil contents. The first arc adapts BOG lasting till episode 13 to 14. The overall story of BOG was interesting and I really don't have much issue with it except some power level plot holes that anime generated.

 The Second arc was pathetic. They just brought back an old villain and use that color changing strategy as lousy excuse for transformation and I don't even wanna start on all detailed plot holes(one example will be breaking of one year revive limit of dragonball). The only good thing that Z warriors actually get a chance to shine.

Third arc bring a battle between two universe but following Budokai Tenkaichi rule (not referring to game but tournament style (u will understand by episode 28)) thus making it like world martial art tournament so again a rip-off plot, the new character design lacked creativity. So majorly tournament wasn't really creative but it somewhat gets interesting near end. 

The fourth arc follows some messing in timeline and DBS after all these years finally introduce a villain with a background and reason for turning evil. The arc actually had a better track, better animation, more intensity and better fights but powers level had been inconsistent through out this arc and the end makes entire arc pointless.

The next proper arc is still to start. Overall the story lack consistency but its enjoyable after second arc.


Characters (5/10)


For old characters, I am really disappointed. Goku became comparatively immature to Z though he wasn't really mature much anyway. Vegeta is a huge let down sure in some ways he has evolved but generally I recognize Vegeta as a symbol of pride but now he is just completely ignoring it rather being more of a Tsundere. Role of rest Z warriors have been negligible.

Ok generally talking about new characters. I already have mentioned that villain with actual reason for going evil and has reasons making him the third DB villain (after Tao and Cell) who just doesn't wanna rule, destroy something(for no creative reason) or have revenge and first villain who basically desires to achieve good but has a twisted philosophy of it. So this is a positive change.

The third arc actually also introduces 2 characters with actual interesting potential.

Now for character that you probably know if you have watched BOG. 

Beerus the God of Destruction. Its basically him, who is keeping the show interesting but what some fans don't realize that he is also a key cause in bringing the show down. As you all shall know he is oppressively strong and Toriyama as he said don't plan to make Goku anyway near his level. And this very fact takes the intensity of the show away. Bcz in show like DBZ, we know heroes had to go all out bcz everything used to be at stake and there was no one beside them who can handle danger. But now we know that even if Z-warriors can't defeat someone, Beerus or some stronger Deus ex machina can come for saving and this knowledge really takes out intensity of show. So basically there are few possibilities that can bring the shows intensity back (a good idea for this is being used for next arc)


Enjoyment (7/10)

My recommendation for enjoying this show. Just enjoy the action and comedy and don't try (too hard) to find explanation for new plot holes and power scaling. I am still unable to enjoy it bcz of it.

In general the series basically relies on nostalgia, comedy and action. Also u might consider this Goku and Vegeta shows in some ways.


Overall (6/10)

So well the average would be 5.6 so almost 6. The show is enjoyable but honestly so far I will say its a worse follow up than GT because I have generally been disappointed be recycled plot, characters and transformation and yes the lack of intensity. GT was horrible too but compare to DBS it was intense and transformation were cooler though recycled plot and characters are there too. But I hope DBS gets better with next saga.

Before I start this review anybody who hasn't seen DB or DBZ this anime might not be as entertaining as DBZ since the cool down periods between fights and the character arcs built over the years play a greater role in DBS than they did in DBZ.   
This anime is the continuation of the granddaddy of all shonen. My ratting for this anime is higher than DBZ, but don't misunderstand. I still  personally love DBZ more and I believe that the fights in DBZ remain more epic than those in DBS. A side note, you should watch the BOG and ROF filmsinstead of the first 25 or so episodes of the anime. The main reason this anime gets a 9 and can possibly even drop down to an 8 is because of these first few episodes. They rehash the 2 films previously mentioned into the anime and on top of that there were certain scenes where the art was horrendous. The films are top quality and you can get more out of the films in a short amount of time. Everything past those episodes is 9-10 if you are a DB/DBZ fan and something between a 7-10 if you are a casual shonen anime fan.  


First lets start with the story. The story of DBS is an improvement upon that of its predecessors. In DB Goku did have some goals like collecting the dragon balls and winning the world martial arts tournaments, but in DBZ it was mostly Goku fighting the next strongest fighter that came along (although I do think the Sayain/Freeza arcs had a good narrative). In DBS the story is mostly about Goku and Vegeta reaching the level of the Gods in terms of power. The story is driven by the mystery about all the other universes outside of the one we have know throughout this franchises history. 


The art, other than the early episodes of the anime are top notch. Its fun to see characters from an old anime in such high quality. The art and animation is especially great when the big climactic fights are happening. Overall great art and animation expected from todays anime. 


The sound is great, character themes always suit the action especially the super saiyan blue theme which always raises the intensity. There are alot of callback to old DBZ themes including the classic DBZ opening theme as background music.


The characters in super are  the old characters we know and love. The great thing about super is all of the main cast get their chance to shine. One thing that was lacking in DBZ was that all our favorite characters from DB where pushed to the wayside in favor of the all powerful saiyan warrior race. Now obviously the saiyans are still more important than the rest of the cast but the spotlight is not as fixated on the saiyans especially in Gokus case. Goku shares the spotlight with Vegeta as main characters of this anime which adds a little diversity in terms of who gets more action.  All the history these characters have built over time comes into play in this anime and as a longtime fan its great to see. Theres a moment between Master Roshi and his students that tugs at the heart strings. They really take advantage of the longtime fans that have special attachments to these characters. They also introduce great new characters like Chompa, Hit, Caulifla, Goku Black,Zamasu and Cabba. All of which are very appealing for the small amount of time we get to spend with them. Also new additions to the main cast like Jacco, Beerus and Whis are intergrated very well and you will grow to like them as much as the old characters.


Obviously I enjoyed this anime very much. I believe if you consider yourself a fan of the dragon ball franchise this anime is a must watch. If you've never watched any dragon ball before I believe you should watch at least DBZ before jumping into this anime. Major improvements to this anime compare to its predecessors are the pacing (Which is shocking because Toei is the anime studio). One major issue with DBZ is the pacing which is not a problem in DBS. Where as in DBZ some major arcs could last 30+ episodes the new major arcs in this anime like the Universe 6 arc and the Goku Black arc are max 15 episodes so all the action and story comes fast. The treatment of the characters as previously mention is much better in DBS and the character development is more spread out. As a longtime fan certain things might bother you like how new characters can achieve legendary old techniques from the past series. This anime is also a great mix of DB and DBZ. It contains the comedy from DB with the cataclysmic fights from DBZ. The comedy is great, I've laughed out loud watching this anime more than any other anime I've ever seen. The fights are still amazing with most major contest being equivalent to those of DBZ. Although, I still think the action in DBZ was better so far...


In conclusion, I definitely think this is a special anime for fans of the franchise and is worthy of a 9-10 rating for those fans. Obviously if you have never liked the franchise the chances of you liking this anime are very slim, unless the improved comedy sways you.

Whereas Dragonball was an adventurous childhood, Dragonball Z was a dramatic adolescence, and GT was the mildlife crisis, Dragonball Super is the senile dotage struggling to recall its glory days. The plot takes fans on a roller coaster ride through peaks of super-powered fights and deep valleys of annoying comedic filler. 
The "Battle of The Gods" saga is a frustrating comedic circus of characters that in which family values and food porn replace martial arts training and quests for dragonballs. The "God of Destruction" instills no fear and inspires no hatred for the audience.
After an anti-climatic ending, the next saga jumps immediately into the action,introducing new villains that quickly act out their evil deeds. Though more action-packed, the "Resurrection of F" story arc relies heavily on nostalgia to make up for the faults of the previous saga. The positive qualities of this saga can be found in flashbacks, returning villains, and fight sequences, though they’re still plagued by comedic distractions like Jaco the space patrolman and strawberry sundaes. \n\n
Unlike these first two sagas, there is no cinematic version for Dragonball Super’s latest saga. This inter-dimensional tournament introduces new characters to provide more combat, however the new characters appear goofy and unappealing, with spaghetti arms and potbellies, while the tougher-looking opponents are simply recycled character designs. Unfortunately, there's more cheating and refereeing than fighting, and there's a complete lack of any side plots or urgency.

So, the thing about Dragon Ball Super is that how much you like it will depend strongly on the first two arcs. The third option is to just skip these first 27 episodes and just watch the movies instead. After episode 28, Dragon Ball Super drastically improves. Basically, if you watch the Battle of Gods movie, episodes 15-18, Resurrection F movie, and then continue with Super after episode 27, you'll be in for a really good time.

What does happen nowadays either in movie or anime making when there are an enormous amount of technical possibilities to create something stunning, something thrilling, gorgeous, satisfying motion picture? Everything is one half-assed. 
 Dragon Ball Super, or I would like to call it "God of Destruction: Untold story of Goku and Vegeta with commentary from everyone else", was greatly awaited by most of its prequel fans, looking forward to how all the modern possibilities will improve all the thrilling action that Dragon Ball is known about. Starting from character designs to action scenes it is expected from viewers to receive exciting sequel toundoubtably one of the greatest anime series that has ever been created. But does it hold up to expectations? Even though the series have only begun, I suppose that this is as good as time as any to write a short review since I do not suspect of it getting any better.


Story


Up until now story have been about Goku and Vegeta (partly) facing the most powerful threat they have ever come across- God of Destruction. In order to beat the new foe, Goku must obtain power called Super Sayan God. 

The things I like in this new plot:

- Enemy this time is not some kind of evil being who tries to take control of world/universe, but instead it is a god that already poses such power that surpasses everyones elses in whole universe;

- God of Destruction is well placed into entire Dragon Ball universe with very believable explenation;

- Explores new dimensions of Sayan power.


 That is it for the good things I can say about the story, now I will get to cons, but since I want to keep it short, I will only name few features I did not enjoy:

- Making all the other characters, except main ones, useless;

- Super Sayan God power makes no sense, whatsoever. If in Dragon Ball GT SS4 was well integrated into story and in its representing universe it seemed very possible and a nice way to upgrade sayan skills to the next level without making them overpowered (well, except for SS4 Gogeta). But now even the idea of someone just suddenly becoming a god seems absurd

-  The beginning of anime was just sterile and lifeless. Crushed my hopes for a great sequel.

- The way story is presented seems like I am watching a cartoon for children.


Art


Visuals for these episodes are fairly good but could have been much better if more time was spent on improving those. What I hated the most was the design of Goku. In the way he is designed now, I do not care how many times he will turn into super sayan god, or how powerful he gets throughout episodes, with this design he looks like a little buffed up wimp.


Characters


Only ones that stood out were Goku, Vegeta (though he mostly seemed more like a circus clown than an actual fighter), Beerus and a little bit Whis. All the other ones where there for few awkward jokes and for commenting and watching Goku fight since they now are totally outclassed. 


Sound


Really enjoyed opening and ending themes, but other than that soundtracks were average.


Other comments


- There are almost no action scenes. and those who are, they are just "meh, it is okay". I miss the thrill from the old series, even Dragon Ball GT. You could feel all those emotions; action and suspense makes you shiver from excitement. 

- Old series I can watch over and over, and over again without getting tire from them, but now you just have to hope that it will get better as time passes. 


(This short review was made after watching 16 episodes and I hope that when it ends my thought will have changed for the better)

I have never written a review before but I want to share my thoughts on how I felt about DBS, so bare with me.
*SPOILERS MAY APPEAR*
Story (6/10):
The story overall wasn't bad, but it wasn't what I expected either. There were certain sagas that could have been written so much better. I was quite disappointed in the first 2 sagas because the transformations and battles just seemed so underwhelming in my opinion. The Resurrection F one really annoyed me because I felt like Freiza should have had more justice to his return, as he is one of the best villains in the Dragon Ball franchise. Itjust didn't seem exciting to me at all, and the battle between Goku and Frieza was not even close to being as good as their first on in DBZ. I also found it pointless on releasing two movies that were practically the first two sagas of the show, you might as well just skip to the third saga if you have seen the movies before the series. These two arcs really turned me off from the series for a bit, but then I decided to continue. As the story progressed, it became better. The Future Trunks arc and The Universal Survival arc were the best out of the series. I felt the tension and sense of danger from the two, and it actually kept me wanting to watch the show more. I will say though that the US arc was dragged out a bit too much, which kinda got me frustrated as the tournament was just under an hour. I also wish that the last episode was an hour long, as the last episode felt a little rush, but I did still like it so it is all good. Overall, it wasn't bad, but like I said, better writing could have made the show much better.


Art (7.5/10):


The art was good, it definitely got better as the series progressed. In terms of animation, it had its good and bad days. Overall, I didn't have a problem with it.


Sound (9/10):


I really liked the soundtracks and sound effects. No complaints about that.


Character (5/10):


This factor is the one that really annoyed me out of the whole entire show.  Let me start off with Goku. I get that Goku has never been the smartest and has been selfish at times, but it seems like Goku has become more dumb and selfish in Super. To me, it seems like Goku has lacked in family values compared to Z, as all he wants to do is train and will do anything to avoid spending time with Chi-chi, his WIFE, and Goten, his YOUNGER SON or go and visit Gohan, Videl and Pan, hell, he even wanted Vegeta to ditch the birth of his daughter just to go train. I don't entirely blame him as it's his Saiyan genes, but Vegeta is Saiyan and seems to be a better family man. Goku also seems to be brain dead at times, not that he wasn't, but Super has pursued this to another level. I'm not too mad about his character overall as he is still one of my favourites, but come on now. However, I'm referring to the Japanese version but possibly some of the dialogue will be changed in the dub. Another thing that pissed me off was how there were a lot of characters pushed to the side or underdeveloped. For example, Yamcha was practically irrelevant in the whole series. Sure, he's not the best fighter or anything, but I feel like he deserved some more respect and be more relevant. I was also disappointed that Goten was irrelevant in the whole series too. The fact he is supposed to be Goku's son, he should have had much more character development and attention, just like Gohan had in Z, it would have been nice to see a journey for him. There are more characters in which I feel the same way but I'm not gonna waffle too much. There were some good new characters I liked, such as Hit, Jiren etc, but I wish Jiren had more of a better introduction and backstory as he was one of the important characters in the final arc.


Enjoyment (8/10):


Despite all the faults I pointed out previously, I still enjoyed the series, and I'm actually gonna miss watching it every Sunday. It still had its great moments and funny humour.


Overall (7-7.5/10):


To conclude, it was still a good show. It may not be as good as DB and DBZ, but it definitely isn't the worst to what people have said, to each its own. To me, I think it is worth a watch. Luckily the series will return in the future, so I hope they will make major improvements, especially in story and character in my opinion.

Here's the long and short of it: Dragon Ball Super isn't that good, and its flaws are huge. On the other hand, it's fun to watch, a testament to the fact that I've willingly stuck with it until now. But I'm going to try to generalize what I feel the show succeeds in and what if fails in -- and why the latter literally doesn't matter.
First let's get this out of the way: this show is a continuation of Dragon Ball, but has only been animated to this point for the sake of merchandising. This may be an oversimplification of the matter, but that isn'tto say this is a bad thing. It's just the nature of the beast when it comes to an IP like Dragon Ball. Is the show bad because of this? Not really. 


My main critique of the plot and the characters boil down to the same argument: too shallow and unchanging. There's an important notion to consider here, that being the fact that most of us watched DB and DBZ as an English dub, and many switched to the sub for the sake of watching Super. Why is this important? Consider Goku. He's just a hillbilly hick who likes to fight. His whole speech after turning super saiyan about being the defender of the so and so and what not? Dubisms, and not in any way an accurate representation of the character. That being said, Super makes a lot more sense when you can turn your brain off and take it for what it is: Goku and friends fighting a lot. The last major villain is dumb as hell story-wise, and -- not to spoil anything -- the major "reveal" in the penultimate episode (regarding the remaining fighters in the tournament) was also dumb as hell. This critique applies to most of the tournament of power arc, but such is the nature when you have to introduce nearly 100 new characters only to eliminate most of them from the series nearly immediately. 

The main characters never really get any more interesting, with a few exceptions (17 gets a lot more showtime in this arc and I love that). Krillin's boring, 18 has a forced character, Gohan is cheated out of any cool scenes, we don't get to see Vegito (a waste, honestly, but I would be more okay with it if they took even five seconds to even mention why they wouldn't fuse in a battle with everything on the line), and Vegeta (while a lot of fun) doesn't really feel the same when they go on about his pride but we don't even get any thoughtful dialogue from him. A lot of wasted potential.


But but but, and here's the thing: while Super isn't an adaptation of a manga, it still has to consider its source material while still keeping up with a weekly release schedule. Rather, an anime of this nature has to play it safe plot-wise, which may explain its general lack of complexity. We can also see that, while quite a few episodes suffer (some more than others) from lack of time and effort, likely for the budget's sake, there are still obvious highlights in each arc for which it seems most of the effort was saved. Tokyo Ghoul season 2 did this, and it looked pretty terrible animation-wise at some points, but I still recognize it's altogether a really good IP. I don't know if I'm going to say the same about Dragon Ball considering a lot of the shit Super has tried to pull (such as the obvious question of how the hell Vegeta managed SSB without attaining SSG but whatever) but I also think we have good reasons for letting this slide.


What baffles me the most in harsh critiques of this show would the the opinions I read on the art and sound. Let's be real, these are the best parts of the series. It sounds good. It may not have the most impressive soundtracks of the DB franchise but it's absolutely fine. I've also put some thought into the yelling of the show, which has become something of a staple of Dragon Ball in general. Those voice actors are good at yelling. There's really not more to say about that, I just appreciate it. And, despite the corners they had to cut animation-wise (as mentioned before), the show looks great as well. Just because a giant red beam colliding with a giant blue one isn't particularly new or intrinsically interesting, it still looks pretty enough and, really, why else do we care? 


Thinking from Funimation's perspective as a company, the lack of "change" we see in the characters makes sense. To get creative and new with an existing character is to risk being scrutinized for not staying true to the established character or something of that nature, although when the established character is bland as hell, that kind of effort would be appreciated (consider Krillin as an example). But, in the end, Super's just fun to watch. Especially after FighterZ's release -- which is possibly the most respectable DB fighting game on the market -- we can see that the "culture" of super has not been sullied when translated to the game format, supporting the notion that Super isn't inherently bad, but can be presented in a fun, appealing way.


A complex story is not necessary for many works, and DBS as an anime is a prime example of this. Note, a better story and more developed characters/drama would have been a very welcome step towards making Dragon Ball a much more quality series toward the end of its life cycle (as of now), but this standard for Dragon Ball hasn't really changed since the Buu Saga in Z.


All in all, it's more Dragon Ball, for whatever that's worth to you.

At the time of this review, approximately 112 episodes have aired, and we are almost done with the much hyped inter dimensional battle royale arc. And at this point I think it is very fair to say that many of the criticisms of this show are very valid. The animation is crap every three episodes (welcome to shounen battle anime), the first two arcs are overly stretched out retellings of the two newest movies (Battle of the Gods and Resurrection F), and the actually new arcs are incredibly underwhelming to say the least. 
In my opinion, the new arcs being underwhelming has everything to dowith the fact that nothing could live up to the hype that much of Dragonball's audience has hyped up in their heads as THE battle anime. Though Akira toriyama has never been one to craft epic stories, he has been commissioned for them since the first time dbz jumped the shark and made goku a space alien. Not to shit on dbf its good mindless fun but thats what it is. mindless. 


I've gotten into a tangent here but my point is that judging DB Super for what it is. It isn't half bad. The action is badass when it wants to (mostly), the plot is best when there is none (hence all the retreading and battle tournaments), and the new characters introduced are sometimes so good I wouldn't mind a spinoff or two following just these new characters. 


TL;DR: Start with episode 35 or so (approx when the original storylines start) and give it a whirl. Id just wait for the dubs for the black goku arc. hearing goku and the gang complain about the horrors caused by "this black guy" is only funny for about five minutes until they start to say it way too much.

Okay, I honestly hate the reception this series has gotten in the past. It had gone through a rough patch when it started and still does go through some of those rough patches to date with its animation and through not explaining things, but I strongly feel that these reviews are not justified in the slightest.
For starters, the first thing that most people would complain about in this series is the way it begun. For those of you that don't know, Dragon Ball Super begins with two sagas that have taken about a third of the series so far. These were adaptations on the moviesthat came before it (and inspired the continuation of the Dragon Ball franchise). A lot of viewers, myself included, were not thrilled by this reveal since we would just have to re-watch everything all over again, and not to mention that the animation in these episodes were not great in comparison to the original movies. But with these adaptations, I think that they brought more to the franchise as a whole, greater fight scenes, better exposition about the super saiyan god (and blue), more character development and not to mention some call-backs to the original series which I think any long time fan would enjoy.


These, are in my opinion the only real factors that people are judging this series on, and it is not a just way to look at it since it is ignoring all of the things that made this series great. For example, the characters in the series and the character development from the returning cast, Vegeta, in particular, displays how much he had grown since his debut in z. He had started from his own selfish desire to get stronger in order to beat Goku and tackle any and every obstacle in his way, even if doing so puts the sake of the world (or universe) at risk. But, in Super, we see him as a more matured character. Right off the bat, we see him spending time with his family in a way nobody would ever dream of from his character in z. Also, as time went on in the series, you truly do see him care more for the world and all the characters within it instead of being focused solely on himself.

The Goku Black arc in the later part of the series brought a more serious tone to the series that haven't really been seen so far in the series, at least not to this extent. This time around, we see that the future is entirely destroyed and the population of Earth is down to around the same number as Earth hada fter Majin Boo's Human extinction attack. Everything looks charred, empty and lifeless as the group of humans from the future tries to hold their own against a threat leagues above them. By the end of the arc, that universe as a whole was destroyed entirely and nothing was left to it, showing a true failure from the cast that we aren't really used to as fans of Dragon Ball. The only solution that the heroes had was to travel back in time and rebuild in that version of Earth. 


Although there are a few things that are bringing the series down, there are still many other upsides that Super brings to the table that sets itself aside from other popular anime out there (engaging relationships, large multiverse and lore, actual entertaining filler episodes, etc.). 

Thanks for reading and give Dragon Ball Super a try if you haven't already:)

Dragon Ball! Oh, Dragon Ball! I have always loved it; it doesn’t matter how many times I visit this world, I always end up admiring its characters, watching them evolve and making their lives grow, experiencing new challenges, and well! What else is to say; Dragon Ball is great! With DBS, I have found myself back in a couch where I used to watch these heroes with my friends. 
Still, there are some flaws, the usual complaint is about the drawing style, and it’s true, it’s ridiculous that TOEI is making this kind of errors with anime as beloved. Also, there are repeating already toldstories, TOEI, yes, we want to see our heroes, but in new stories!  And well, the other thing is about the characters; Goku is just plain stupid, I mean, we have always known how Goku is, how innocent and naive can be, but he is just so dumb that if he would have to live in a world as his, it cannot be! Also (spoiler ahead), he gets everyone in danger by an idiotic decision, the thing that would never happen with the old Goku, because even if he is as fanatic fighter as he is, he also worries and loves everyone and everything where he lives. 


There are also kudos for this anime, the new opening is fantastic, characters such as the God of Destruction (Beerus-sama) have made of this new story and engaging one, active, dynamic, and something it make you think and feel. 


I would recommend everyone to watch this anime, more if you are an old-time fan.
